title: brave woman shares final request
story: Brave woman shares final request with family before losing battle with cystic fibrosisKayley Keri, , was born with the genetic disease and died just before her st birthday in December  - her family are getting ready to mark the anniversary of the Liverpool womans deathKayley Keir, , died in December  after battling cystic fibrosis her entire le Image: Liverpool EchoByTom DuffyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A brave woman shared her final request with her family before losing her lelong battle with cystic fibrosis.Kayley Keri, , was born with the genetic disease and became the youngest patient to have a heart-lung transplant at the age of .Kayley, from Liverpool, died in December  shortly before her st birthday.Her family are not preparing to mark the sixth anniversary of her death and are determined to raise awareness for cystic fibrosis , Liverpool ECHO reports. They also revealed Kayleyaposs final request before her death and said it was to remember her for the dference she made. In a statement, the family said: Behind closed doors, the grief isn’t any easier.  Not once in the last six years have we not spoken about Kayley, she is still very much the focal point in our family and will always be. Kayley is in our conversations every day whether we are saying how she would have liked something or discussing a memory. She is still a huge part of us all. They said their grief had been exacerbated by the death of Kayleyaposs many friends within the CF community.  They said: Sadly most of the CF friends of Kays have also passed on, what was once a close-knit group have all gained their wings, with just a couple of Kayaposs CF friends remaining. The grief and sadness we feel for Kay only gets harder, each time a friend of heraposs passes. They added: We know Kay was aiming for a better outcome for CF patients, we pray that all Kayaposs hard work and fight against CF has been beneficial for others. They described Kayley as the funniest and most courageous person who everyone could rely on for honest advice.  The family also revealed Kayleyaposs heartbreaking final request. They said: Kay requested the Beyoncé song - aposI was hereapos as she wanted to be remembered not for CF alone but for the dference she made, this song was the way she told us after she had passed the way she wanted it to be. Kay was very strong-minded, even going as far in her last few years of telling people little things she would likethat last day ever came.  This was how we pieced together Kayaposs beautul funeral. Never a spoken plan but yet a plan of Kayaposs own. As a family we are still extremely thankful to all the staff at Liverpool Heart and Chest, Alder Hey Hospital and Wythenshawe for the years of dedicated care for Kay and supporting us as a family, not forgetting Great Ormond Street who performed Kayaposs transplant and the family that sadly lost their child but yet gave us the gt of le. We can never show our gratitude but these people and places will remain in our hearts forever. title: bus driver 57 sacked being
story: Bus driver, , sacked for being too short is overwhelmed after support from celebsCelebrities including Bolton-born actress Maxine Peake and Coronation Street star Julie Hesmondhalgh have sent messages of support to bus driver Tracey Scholes - who is locked in an employment battle with bus operator Go North West LtdTracey Scholes was one of the first females on the job when she started driving buses in Greater Manchester  years agoByThomas MolloyRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec  A bus driver sacked for being too short says she is overwhelmed after receiving heartwarming messages of support from local celebrities.Widowed mum Tracey Scholes, , was one of the first women driving buses in Greater Manchester when she started  years ago. But last month, bosses at bus operator Go North West Ltd gave Tracey her notice - ruling that she was no longer tall enough to safely drive their vehicles, according to Unite the Union. The trade union said Tracey was offered an alternative role in the company, but one with fewer hours and less pay - which would leave her in financial hardship.Tracey was handed her -week notice after refusing the new position. She is now appealing the decision, Manchester Evening News reports. In the days since her battle was made public, Bolton-born actress Maxine Peake, Coronation Street star Julie Hesmondhalgh, and actor James Quinn, have all got in touch to offer words of support, Tracey said.I could have never expected anything like this, she said. Iaposm overwhelmed and so emotional with it at the minute. People are getting in touch with me who I donapost even know. Itaposs been absolutely lovely to get that response, itaposs like one big family. As part of the fight for Tracey to keep her job, her colleagues have started a petition which now has more than , signatures. A Unite the union spokesman said: “Tracey is a hardworking, loved and a valued member of the NW    Branch and the Queens Road family who deserves to be commended for her years of service to the traveling public of Greater Manchester. “However Go North West Ltd has dismissed her from employment because they changed the manufacturer specication on their fleet of buses resulting in five foot tall Tracey being physically unable to operate company vehicles safely.  “Go North West Ltd have refused to consider proposals from Tracey and her Unite trade union reps to keep her in employment. “This has resulted in her unfair dismissal from Go North West Ltd for capability to fulfil her role a PCV driver. “The company’s only resolution is to offer Tracey a position in the company that would see Tracey’s pay and hours cut signicantly leaving her in financial hardship. A spokesman from Go North West, which runs  routes, mostly in North Manchester, said: “We are extremely proud of our team of drivers who continue to perform excellent work keeping the people of Manchester moving. Unfortunately, a situation has arisen where we have had to bring a driver’s employment to an end. This is a complex case, and the appeals process is ongoing. Therefore, we are unable to comment further at this stage. title: bus driver sacked being short
story: Bus driver is sacked for being too short after  years on the jobWidowed mum Tracey Scholes, one of few women in the job when she started driving buses in Greater Manchester, says she was given her notice last monthTracey Scholes said that she has been sacked for being too short Image: MEN MEDIAByCharlotte CoxTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA bus driver with  years of experience claims she has been sacked for being too short after wing mirrors on the vehicles were repositioned. Tracey Scholes, who is five feet, says she was one of few women in the job when she started driving buses in Greater Manchester.On her first day in , she recalls a very frosty reception and says there weren’t even female toilets on the Cheetham Hill site, reported the Manchester Evening News.But trailblazer Tracey remained at the depot with First bus and then Go North West, when they took over in , and it was a devastating blow when she was given her notice last month. The reason, claims Unite union, is that since the operator has repositioned its wing mirrors, Tracey is too short to use them at the same time as reaching the pedals. Unite claims Tracey was told she no longer had the capability to safely drive the buses and she was offered an alternative role at the company, but for less hours and pay. Tracey declined and was given  weeksapos notice, a decision she is now appealing. Tracey, , from Heywood, said: “This is heartbreaking. I’m a widow with three children, a house and a mortgage and it’s nearly Christmas. “I’ve never had to involve the union before, I’ve never had a disciplinary, never been suspended. “I’ve always gone to management myself with any issues and worked it through.” Tracey said the firm began replacing broken branch mirrors to the side of the windscreen with side mirrors, around two years ago. When Tracey tried to drive these buses, she’d have to lean around a pillar on the cab assault screen to see the mirror, meaning her feet lted off the pedals. Tracey brought this to management’s attention and bosses assigned her routes driving single and double deckers with the old-style mirrors, she claims. Tracey was most recently assigned the  route from Shudehill to Prestwich, and says she would increasingly arrive on sht to find the tricky wing mirrors. “It’s one of the most important pieces of equipment on the bus. You need it to turn a corner or pull into a bus stop. When you turn you need to watch that mirror to see the angles on the back wheel so you don’t clip a curb,” said Tracey. “For years I could drive everything in the garage. But I was running out of buses I could drive.” She added: I’m flabbergasted that they can just get rid of me after  years. I love my job, I don’t want to lose it. I have regular customers and a regular route.  Tracey has been moved by the outpouring of support from her colleagues. I work with such a great bunch of lads. They are lovely, she said. “I’ve had such tremendous support with this. It’s just blown me away.” As part of the fight for Tracey to keep her job, her colleagues have started a petition which now has more than , signatures. A Unite the union spokesman said: “Tracey is a hardworking, loved and a valued member of the NW   Branch and the Queens Road family who deserves to be commended for her years of service to the traveling public of Greater Manchester. “However Go North West Ltd has dismissed her from employment because they changed the manufacturer specication on their fleet of buses resulting in five foot tall Tracey being physically unable to operate company vehicles safely. “Go North West Ltd have refused to consider proposals from Tracey and her Unite trade union reps to keep her in employment. “This has resulted in her unfair dismissal from Go North West Ltd for capability to fulfil her role a PCV driver. “The company’s only resolution is to offer Tracey a position in the company that would see Tracey’s pay and hours cut signicantly leaving her in financial hardship. A spokesman from Go North West, which runs  routes, mostly in North Manchester, told MEN: “We are extremely proud of our team of drivers who continue to perform excellent work keeping the people of Manchester moving. Unfortunately, a situation has arisen where we have had to bring a driver’s employment to an end. This is a complex case, and the appeals process is ongoing. Therefore, we are unable to comment further at this stage. title: couple bring stray cat found
story: Exclusive: Couple bring stray cat found on Greek island , miles to live with them in UKJulie LeMilliere and husband Neil feared one-year-old stray cat Roo would not last the winter so they went to get her from the Greek Island, beginning a , mile round tripJulie LeMillieres husband Neil LeMilliere used planes, trains and automobiles to make a , mile round trip for Roo the catByAndy Gardner:,  Dec | commentsJulie LeMilliere vowed never to get another cat when her -year-old had to be put down in April. But she bonded with a stray moggy with a dodgy eye while staying on a Greek island in September. She and husband Neil feared one-year-old Roo would not last the winter. So he made a , mile round trip involving trains, ferries, taxis and a plane to bring him home to London as a th birthday present for his we. Julie, a PA for a law firm, said: “I was heartbroken when my cat Tis passed away but being with Roo made me realise I could have a pet again.” Neil, , said: “Julie and Roo just bonded and by the end of our break, they were inseparable. “He was a stray, but used to be looked after by the lady who ran the hotel we stayed in at Batsi.” The couple, from Haringey, North London, ed to England from Andros on September . They had spent hundreds of pounds with a local vet getting Roo vaccinated, chipped and protected from rabies.But days before they had to leave, they were told new Brexit rules meant Roo could not travel as hand luggage.Before Brexit it would have cost them £ to fly him back but now he had to go in the hold at a cost of more than £,.  So the couple left Roo with the hotel owner and hatched a cunning plan. On October , Neil drove to Folkestone, caught the Eurotunnel to Lille in France, where he hopped on a train to Paris. He then caught a plane to Athens airport, a bus to the ferry port of Rafina, took a -minute boat to Andros and a taxi to the resort of Batsi. Less than  hours later, Neil and Roo began thejourney, arriving home at .am on October . Read more The rescue cost the couple over £ but Neil said: “It is absolutely worth it.” Julie added: “It’s wonderful and he is now sat on a soft cushion in our kitchen, safe, warm, well-fed and remarkably untraumatised!” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cats" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid claims 127 more lives
story: Covid claims  more lives as UK records second highest case count in EuropeCovid deaths and hospitalisations are much lower now than this time last year in the UK, government stats show, despite the coronavirus case count being roughly three times as highMore than , people have now lost their lives to Covid- in the UK Image: Getty ImagesByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A further  people have lost their lives to Covid- in the UK, government stats show.The official death toll from the deadly virus now stands at , across the course of the pandemic. Coronavirus cases recorded remain steady compared to the previous two Saturdayaposs, with todayaposs , slightly up from , seven days ago and , the week before that.Only Germany, which logged more than , positive tests yesterday, is dealing with more cases.The data comes at the end of a concerning week, with the arrival of the Omicron iant on British shores forcing Boris Johnson to insist that Christmas will go ahead as normal.However, comparison with figures from this time last year suggests further restriction are not out of the question.  On this date in ,  people died of Covid - more than three times more than the death toll today. A total of , people were in hospital with the disease as of Thursday, half that of the , on the same date last year. However, , cases were logged - a third of the number today. The dference between this year and last is the vaccine, which has drastically cut hospitalisations and deaths despite the case count being signicantly higher than  months ago. If scientistsapos worse fears about Omicron are realised, then the wall of protection offered by the vaccine may be breached and more stringent coronavirus restrictions reintroduced.  The mutant strain has around  mutations on its spike protein, meaning it may be able to neutralise the effect of antibodies. In recognition of the threat Omicron poses, Downing Street reintroduced mask mandates on public transport and in shops this week. At the time Johnson said: “Our scientists are learning more hour by hour, and it does appear that Omicron spreads very rapidly, and can be spread between people who are double vaccinated.” Asked about the prospect for this year’s festivities, and whether any more restrictions would be introduced, the PM said: “We continue to be in a strong position largely thanks to the speed of the vaccine rollout, another booster rollout and I think I’m going to stick with the formula I’ve used before, which is I’m pretty confident to absolutely confident this Christmas will be considerably better than last Christmas.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: edinburgh zoo send 2 giant
story: UKs only two giant pandas may be sent back to China after failure to breedTian Tian and Yang Guang were flown from the Sichuan province in China to Edinburgh Airport in  via the specially chartered FedEx Panda ExpressTian Tian and Yang Guang may have to go back to China Image: SWNSByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsEdinburgh Zoo might have to send their two giant pandas, Tian Tian and Yang Guang, back to China after the pair have been living there for a decade. The zoo shared its worries about the two pandas in a social media post that celebrated their  year anniversary. Despite many attempts, both natural breeding and articial insemination, the pair have not managed to breed during their time at the zoo. Thousands of visitors flock to the Scottish tourist attraction each year to see the pair. The zooaposs post read: Ten years ago today we welcomed a very special package! What a decade itaposs been since Tian Tian and Yang Guang arrived in Edinburgh.  We still hope to extend their stay and remain in talks with our colleagues in China. Weaposll update everyone as soon as we can. Edinburgh Zoo, which pays about one million dollars a year to rent the pandas, had been hoping to reach a new lease agreement with China in summer of this year, according to a Freedom of Information request put in by Deadline News. In January , RZSS’s chief executive David Field sent an email saying: “The agreement was signed in January , but the effective end is December . “Any new extension should be agreed by June .” It was initially hoped that Tian Tian and Yang Guang would breed and produce panda cubs in Scotland. Unfortunately they have not done so. The two pandas were flown to Edinburgh Airport from the Sichuan province in the aposFedEx Panda Expressapos cargo plane in . It was specically chartered for their journey. title: healthy man 30 left two
story: Healthy man, , left two hours from death describes struggle with CovidWithin days of displaying the telltale symptoms of a fever and persistent cough, Aled Davies went rapidly downhill and needed an urgent admission to hospitalAled Davies, , from Tredegar, was severely unwell with Covid- and almost died Image: Glenn DeneByMark Smith:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A -year-old man has described his struggle with Covid- after being left a couple of hours away from death. Aled Davies tested positive for coronavirus last August despite being double jabbed.But as he spent most of his le in relatively good health with only a broken arm and the removal of a cyst blotting his NHS notes, he didnapost foresee what was to come.Within days of displaying the telltale symptoms of a fever and persistent cough, the -year-old went rapidly downhill and needed an urgent admission to hospital. His breathing deteriorated to such an extent that his lungs completely failed and left him just a couple of hours from death.My body had deteriorated so much that they phoned my parents to say that I probably wouldnapost come out of this alive. My lungs just couldnapost take the infection, he told Wales Online.  Support worker Aled, who tested positive for Covid on August , said he was about to come out of his -day isolation when he woke up on September  unable to breathe.I didnapost lose my taste or smell, but I did have every other symptom including body aches, headaches, and I couldnapost sleep, said Aled, whose entire family became unwell with the virus.The first day [I tested positive] I was alright, but then things got worse and worse until I couldnapost breathe, I couldnapost talk and my lips turned blue. Soon after dialling , paramedics from the Welsh Ambulance Service arrived at his home in Tredegar and rushed him to The Grange University Hospital in Cwmbran where he was immediately given breathing support. But after a couple of days in isolation on a Covid ward he needed to be taken to intensive care, placed on a ventilator and put in an induced coma. Obviously I was nervous about it. I knew how serious it was to be put on a ventilator but the doctors knew what was best for me, he said. After three days on a ventilator, hospital staff could see no improvement in Aledaposs lungso the decision was made to transfer him by ambulance to Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Hospital in London where he would be put on an ECMO machine.  The machine acted as an articial lung for Aled while his own lungs were drained of infection and given a much-needed rest. They had to drain all the blood out of my body on the one side and push it back through the other side with fresh oxygenated blood because I wasnapost producing oxygen, he explained. You have to meet a certain criteria to even go on an ECMO machine, so I was very lucky. Itaposs used as a last resort when all other options have failed. Thankfully Aled responded well on the machine and came off it four days later. He was then taken by air ambulance back to The Grange University Hospital for further treatment. I woke up [from the coma] on September  and I didnapost have a clue what had happened. If theyaposd told me Iaposd just been ventilated at The Grange and stayed there I would have believed them. I had stitches everywhere and a million tubes in me, he recalled. Aled, who spent his th birthday in hospital, admitted that he thought his parents would be far more unwell than him as they both have autoimmune disorders.  There is no explanation as to why I had it so bad. Iaposve always been prone to coughs and chest infections but Iaposve never been diagnosed with any underlying conditions. My lungs took a hiding - they just couldnapost handle it. After a brief stint in Nevill Hall Hospital after his transfer from The Grange, Aled was discharged on September  - but he still had to learn to walk again and build up his strength. I lost three-and-a-bit stone in  days. I lost all the muscles in my legs and arms - they shrunk to nothing. I also had to walk with a stick. It took me half an hour to get up a flight of stairs when I got out, he said. I bought a personal trainer plan so Iaposve just been looking at that. Driving again was also a big relief. Some days Iaposm absolutely fine and getting my steps in, but other times Iaposm so tired I just need to stay in bed.Aled heaped praise on NHS staff throughout his coronavirus treatment and admitted he wouldnapost have survived without them.Thereaposs a lot of frustration with the NHS, but the staff were incredible. I didnapost come across a single person who wasnapost helpful. Everyone at The Grange was class, the set-up was class and they just donapost get the credit they deserve. Staff at Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Hospital and Nevill Hall were also amazing. Following his ordeal, Aled has urged people to follow government guidelines, wear masks and continue to get vaccinated, particularly with the new Omicron iant. He is now looking forward to playing more gigs with his two rock bands, De’Lour and Sentry, and continue running Unit  Music Studio as he strives to make a full recovery. news uk-news horric-clips-show-flushed-out-"Shocking footage of foxes fed to hounds on Scottish huntsByMark McGivernChief Reporter:,  Dec | commentsShocking footage appearing to show foxes being fed to baying hounds during hunts have been released.Animal rights activists shared a horric showreel they claim highlights practices which are deeply ingrained in the fox-hunting community. The League Against Cruel Sports video shows a fox fed to the dogs after being legally flushed out, the Daily Record reported. It follows another video published two weeks ago in which a man was seen tossing a fox to dogs and encouraging them to rip it apart at a hunt in Howwood, Renfrewshire.Robbie ­Marsland, spokesperson for the League Against Cruel Sports, said the footage showed that the cruelty involved in fox hunting is alive and well, despite the law banning the dogs from hunting down the animals in the traditional way. Mr Marsland said: “If hunts were obeying the law, the dogs would be used to flush a fox from cover where it could then be shot – but where’s the fun in that  “Traditional hunting ­celebrates the suffering and the kill. Throwing dead foxes to dogs ensures they continue to have the taste for blood, and subsequently the desire to kill. “The footage shows that hunters are not ready to give this element of their sport up. “It is just one of the routine and systematic ways the pro-hunting lobby uses to try to keep their cruel sport alive.”  The three latest incidents documented include the Fe Hunt, Lindores, in March , the Duke of Buccleuch Hunt in the Borders in March , and the Berwickshire Hunt in Abbey St Bathans in November . Each shows a dead fox being thrown to a pack of dogs. Although fox hunting with dogs was banned in Scotland in , an unlimited number of dogs are allowed to chase foxes from cover so they can be shot. Glasgow Hunt Sabs said members watched a fox being driven towards a line of guns and shot dead during the Lanarkshire and Renfrewshire Hunt.  The group claimed they watched a “legal kill facilitated by illegal actions”, saying hunting laws were breached when the animal was chased by hounds over open ground. They said: “If it’s not illegal, it’s morally disgusting. Surely this isn’t pest control.” In April, the Scottish Greens called for a total ban on fox hunting, saying loopholes must be closed to put a stop to all “cruel” killings by hunts with dogs. The three hunts were approached for comment. title: lenient sentences stepmum dad who
story: Lenient sentences for stepmum and dad who killed Arthur, , to be referredEmma Tustin, , was told she must serve a minimum of  years in prison after being found guilty of the murder of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, while his father Thomas Hughes, was told he must serve a minimum of  years for manslaughterArthur Labinjo-Hughes died aged six Image: PAByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec | commentsThe lenient prison sentences handed to the killers of six-year-old Arthur Labinjo-Hughes are set to be referred to the Attorney General. Emma Tustin, , was told she must serve a minimum of  years in prison after being found guilty of the murder of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, while his father Thomas Hughes, was told he must serve a minimum of  years for manslaughter. Solihull MP Julian Knight warned their case will be passed onto the Attorney General as he lay flowers outside Arthuraposs home on Saturday, according to reports. It means there is a chance the pairaposs sentence could be extended. Speaking in Solihull on Saturday, Mr Knight said to the Daily Mail : There’s a palpable sense of real loss and tragedy over this and also, frankly, a sense of anger, and questions over how this was allowed to happen, how these monsters were allowed to inflict this horrible torture on this young, defenceless boy.My view is very simple on this. We need to get to the bottom of how this happened and we need to ensure that those who have failed him are accountable. But also I think anyone reflecting on those sentences yesterday thinks that they were too lenient and my intention is to refer this to the unduly lenient sentencing scheme as soon as possible and I will be doing that on Monday morning. Arthur was left with an unsurvivable brain injury while in the sole care of evil Tustin. She was jailed for le with a minimum term of  years at Coventry Crown Court on Friday, after being convicted of murder by assaulting defenceless Arthur in the hallway of her home in Solihull, on June , . Arthur, whose body was also covered in  bruises, died in hospital the next day.  Manipulative and calculating Tustin was unanimously convicted after an eight-week trial trial, with the boyaposs pitiless father Hughes found guilty of his manslaughter, after encouraging the killing. Hughesapos infatuation for Tustin had obliterated any love for his son, the sentencing judge said. title: man creates spectacular christmas display
story: Man creates spectacular Christmas display after hes diagnosed with leukaemiaPeter Elliott has spent a month putting up thousands of lights on his home in Romford, east London, as well as Santas grotto with rocking horses, five Father Christmases, elves, reindeer and starsPeter Elliott has spent a month putting up thousands of lights Image: PAByIsobel Frodsham:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A man diagnosed with leukaemia is raising money for a blood cancer charity through an elaborate Christmas display outside his home.Peter Elliott has spent a month putting up thousands of lights on his home in Romford, east London, to raise money for Leukaemia Care and Great Ormond Street Hospital. The -year-old creates the display each year to raise money for GOSH and other charities, but decided to raise funds for the cancer charity this year following his treatment. Mr Elliott was diagnosed with leukaemia in February . He created a pared-down display last year as he had Covid- at the time. However this year the display has ed to its full glory and features Santaaposs grotto with rocking horses, five Father Christmases, elves, reindeer and stars  . There is also a ft star on the roof of his home, which he shares with his partner Lesley Haylett, . Mr Elliott said: Iaposve been doing it every year for about  years. Every year I try to do something dferent - so Iaposve built gingerbread houses, castles, piratesapos things, lots of dferent things. Every year we raise money for GOSH because my grandchild was in Great Ormond Street years ago, and this year Leukaemia Care, because theyaposve been really supportive after I was told my blood count was low and needed to be checked out. I just think itaposs a good way to show your appreciation. He added: It started off with just a string of lights. Weaposve got some elderly people who live across the road and they sent us a Christmas card saying how much they liked the lights, and itaposs just grown from there. People come and see it from all over. One feature from the coupleaposs display is missing this year. Two ft statues of comics Laurel and Hardy, which Ms Haylett bought for her partner  years ago, were stolen from outside their home in the summer.  A £, reward for their safehas been offered by Dean Floyd, on behalf of his construction company, Chigwell Group, but the statues have not been seen since. It was the fourth time they had been stolen. Last time they ed after three years. Mr Elliott said: Hopefully theyaposll come back. I was gutted when they were nicked again. The house is known for them and the Christmas decorations. I found out theyaposd been taken when I was in hospital for a bone marrow transplant. They didnapost want to tell me theyaposd gone again. He added that he was delighted that he was able to make the display this year as it was a little touch and go because of his diagnosis. It feels terric to see it done, he said. Ms Haylett said: Weaposre really proud of him. A lot of people get cancer and then just lock themselves away. But heaposs just been trying to carry on as he always does. title: mirror newspaper tablet offer promotion

title: mum looked like elephant man
story: Mum looked like Elephant Man as her head swelled up after hair dye useAnita Benton, from Sheldon, West Midlands, said she was temporarily blinded for four days and fears shell have permanent eyelid damage after suffering a severe allergic reaction to the Schwarzkopf Live dyeAnita Bentons face became very swollen Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHelen Le Caplain:,  Dec | commentsA mum has vowed to never dye her hair again after an allergic reaction left her looking aposlike the Elephant Manapos. Anita Bentonaposs face swelled dramatically and her skin erupted in a red, lumpy rash after dying her hair using the Schwarzkopf product last month, she has claimed. The -year-old said she was temporarily blinded for four days and fears sheaposll have permanent eyelid damage after suffering a severe allergic reaction to the Schwarzkopf Live dye in shade Cosmic Blue. Anita thought she wouldnapost need a patch test as she has used the product every six to eight weeks since  with no problems. But just  minutes after applying the dye on October , the mum-of-three claims her scalp started aposburningapos.  The following day it was weeping so much her hair aposstuck to her headapos. Over the next two days her Anitaaposs ballooned, swelling so much so her eyelids closed over, leaving her unable to see and forcing her to take a week off work. Anitaaposs concerned boss asked for pictures of her medication to prove she was having an allergic reaction and wasnapost the victim of a vicious beating - while even her own dad didnapost recognise her. A Schwarzkopf spokesman said they have offered expert help to identy the cause of her reaction and urge everyone to an allergy alert test before using hair colour. Anita, from Sheldon, West Midlands, said: I looked like Elephant Man. I took a selfie and sent it to my dad and he replied aposwhoaposs that apos. Even my own dad couldnapost recognise me. My manager asked me to send her pictures of my medication to prove I hadnapost been beaten up and that it was actually an allergic reaction. Iaposm never dying my hair again, Iaposm going to go grey gracefully.  Anita was refreshing her hair colour using the dye in Cosmic Blue - a blue black shade sheaposd previously used with no problem. However, just  minutes after putting the product on her hair her scalp started burning so she washed it off. That evening her head started to itch and weep and she was unable to sleep due to the discomfort. Over the next two days her face ballooned, her eyes closed over and her head started to itch and weep. Anita called her GP at am on Monday, October th who suggested she go to Birmingham Midland Eye Centre. There, doctors ran tests and referred her to Heartlands Hospitalaposs AE department in Birmingham, West Midlands, where she was prescribed steroids and antibiotics. Days later the swelling started to subside but then Anita broke out in a lumpy, itchy rash that required another two lots of steroids, steroid cream and stronger antihistamines.  Anita said: Iaposve naturally dark hair, I had a few greys coming through so I thought aposright letaposs sort those greys outapos. Iaposve been using the same hair dye since  and never had any problems. I donapost patch test every time, I just did it on the first one. You usually leave your hair dye on for half an hour, as per the instructions, I had it on  minutes and I could feel this burning and tingling feeling. Then the burning just got too much so I washed it off. On Sunday morning I woke up and all my hair was stuck to my head because it had been weeping throughout the night. Later in the night there was a little bit of swelling by my left temple. I didnapost manage to sleep that night, the stuff weeping out of my scalp was running down my face and it was so itchy, I was dying to scratch it. I phoned my GP, he asked me to send some photos and because my eyes were swollen he told me to go to the eye hospital. When I got outside the hospital I could feel both my eyes swelling up that much that they were closing. They put loads of drops in my eyes, said there was no problem with them, and said I needed to go to AE. As soon as the doctor there saw me he said straightaway aposhair dyeapos. He gave me steroids and antibiotics and told me to buy some Piriton to relieve the itching. Both of my eyes completely closed, I could only open my eyes on Thursday.  The swelling went from my eyes and dropped down into my cheeks so I looked like a hamster, then my skin broke out in a rash all over. There were bumps underneath my skin, it was that itchy I was ripping myself to pieces. I went back to the doctor and he said I had a skin infection and I had another two lots of steroids and stronger antihistamines and some steroid cream. All in all I had eight or nine dferent medications and I pay for my prescriptions. While in hospital waiting to be seen, Anita contacted Schwarzkopf in a bid to get to the bottom of what had triggered her reaction. Anita says she was told a aposminor change to the perfume ingredientapos had been made and the hair giant have also offered to pay for dermatological testing. After finishing her course of antibiotics, Anita is now fully recovered apart from a aposbaggyapos left eyelid that she hopes will go back to normal in due course. Anita said: Iaposm fully recovered and back to normal now. Where it swelled up my eyelid hasnapost gone back to normal, itaposs a bit baggier than it was, but I just keep putting on loads of cream and hoping for the best. I want to raise awareness because a lot of women like myself donapost do patch tests purely because weaposve been using the same hair dye for years and years. These companies change their products all of the time, all they need to do is put a little sticker on that says aposnew and improved, please re-do your patch testapos. A Schwarzkopf spokesperson said: We were sorry to hear about Anita Bentonaposs experience and wish her a speedy recovery. She has been in contact with us and we have offered expert help to identy the cause of her reaction. We urge everyone to read the instructions and do an allergy alert test before using hair colour, eventhey have used the brand or specic colour before, as allergies can build up over time. title: mums year long nightmare after
story: Mums year-long nightmare after HMRC gives her £, by mistakeSelf-employed mum Helen Peters "nightmare" started when HMRC accidentally deposit £, into her bank account - which they have now retrievedA self-employed mum found HMRC had deposited a massive £, in her bank accountByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA woman who was accidentally paid £, by HMRC says she spent a year in a nightmare as she waited for the taxman to reclaim it.Helen Peters, a pseudonym used to conceal the womanaposs identity, said she felt like she was in a Hollywood film when the le-changing sum dropped in her bank account.The mum waited another  months, hoping HMRC would realise their huge mistake and retrieve it, the Manchester Evening News reports.But during the pandemic work dried up for self-employed Peters, and she dipped into the cash - spending £, to keep herself afloat. She said: It was like something out of a Hollywood film, and after I had got over the shock I just assumed that someone would realise that they had made a huge mistake and that they would swtly take the money back.  But no one did, and the money just sat in my account.”With the money still in her account, Peters contacted thenewspaper because she wanted tothe enormous sum.Peters said: I assumed that HMRC staff would notice their mistake when I paid my tax in November , but nothing happened. “I even tried to ring HMRC but getting hold of anyone at the time was impossible. I’d wait  minutes on the phone and then would have to give up as my child would need to be fed, or something.  “On other calls, I would be cut off before I could talk to someone. I moved £, into my savings account but it has earned virtually no interest. I have never been wealthy and don’t have a car or even a dog. My income had been decimated and all the time I was very gently eating into the money. But because I could no longer pay the whole sum back I was stuck in a catch- position. I had a whole load of money I knew I couldn’t spend, but I was unable to do anything about it in case HMRC wanted it all back at once.” After trying to get advice from a few people, she was met with ied words of wisdom.  Some told her to do nothing with the money while others advised her to invest it in shares or property, hoping no one would ask for the money back. Out of desperation to recover the money she spent, Peters considered investing the cash into cryptocurrency.discovered that HMRC staff made the payment by accident after trying to pay Peters a £. parcel customs duty rebate. Had she never came forward, thereaposs a good chance the payment would never have been discovered. Upon discovering the mistake, HMRC brought up a case on behalf of Section A of the Theft Act . The law states that keeping wrongful credit and not taking reasonable steps to cancel the credit is unlawful. We are sorry for the inconvenience caused to the inidual, a HMRC spokesperson said. We are working to recover the payment that was made. For the amount that the inidual spent, we will work with them to come to a payment arrangement that takes into account their financial circumstances. Peters will apparently be contacted by debt management advisers to establish a reasonable way to pay the money back with monthly payments. She has offered to pay back the balance over a span of five years. title: mum thanks staff who helped
story: Mum thanks staff who helped Christmas miracle baby born with devastating conditionPreston Mark Middleton was diagnosed with Spina Bida and Hydrocephalus. His mum gave birth when she was  weeks pregnant in a bid to repair his spine. She has now thanked medical staffDeborah and David with their baby Preston at his christening Image: chroniclelive BySophie FinneganChiara FiorilloNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA mum has thanked medical staff who helped her Christmas miracle baby who was diagnosed with a devastating health condition. Preston Mark Middleton was diagnosed with Spina Bida, which happens when a babyaposs spine and spinal cord does not develop properly in the womb, causing a gap in the spine. Doctors also found the little boy had Hydrocephalus, a build-up of fluid in the brain.The excess fluid puts pressure on the brain, which can damage it, the NHS explains. Mum Deborah, , underwent fetal surgery in Belgium when she was  weeks pregnant in a bid to repair her sonaposs spine, Chronicle Live reports.Now, the woman and the boyaposs dad David, , have thanked hospital staff as the family prepares to celebrate their first Christmas together, with Preston approaching his first birthday.  Deborah said: Me and David are so incredibly grateful for all the staff that helped us. We didnapost know what the surgery would be like, we didnapost know how Preston would be now. We do know itaposs helped him a great deal, heaposs meeting all his milestones and doing everything a typical child does. Weaposre incredibly grateful to the NHS who talked us through the surgery and gave it as an option. Weaposre just so blessed we were actually able to get the surgery as there is a lot of criteria to meet and some families arenapost as lucky as us.Deborah said she was told during her -week pregnancy scan that something was not quite right and that there was an abnormality in Prestonaposs brain. The following week, the mum had an appointment at Newcastleaposs Royal Victoria Infirmary where doctors confirmed that Preston had the birth defect which can cause weakness or total paralysis of the legs. The condition also caused a Chiari II malformation, a condition of the cerebellum that can put pressure on parts of the brain and spinal cord. Following the fetal surgery, Preston was born via a C-section on December , , but remained in intensive care while doctors monitored his progress before ing home on December . Due to hospital appointments and lockdowns, last year the family could not celebrate Christmas, but they are now looking forward to the festive period.  Deborah said: Preston was born on December  and we werenapost surewe would be able to leave the hospital for Christmas Day but we came home the day before Christmas Eve which was just amazing. We got to spend Christmas together as a family with our parents and it was lovely but I feel like this Christmas is our first proper one. Last year we had just got out of the hospital and we were in lockdown and now Preston is a bit older heaposs starting to take notice of everything. Just to be able to do all the festive activities with him and live a relatively typical le is just amazing. We have been to see Santa and weaposve planned Prestonaposs first birthday party. It will be really good to get family and friends together to celebrate after everything weaposve been through and everything everyone has been through with lockdown.  Deborah has thanked her loved ones for all their support, adding: David has been amazing with how strong he has been and how well he has coped with everything. I couldnapost wish for a better husband and a better father for Preston. I donapost know where Iaposd be without my mam too, weaposre really close. Deborah and David have since thanked all the NHS staff at the RVI Newcastle and neonatal intensive care as well as the team in Belgium for carrying out the fetal surgery. After initially being given a bleak outlook, Deborah said Preston has come on leaps and bounds and is meeting all his key milestones one year on calling him their Christmas miracle. She said: We didnapost know what to think when we got the diagnosis, I probably didnapost think Preston would ever do the things heaposs doing now. They didnapost think Preston would be able to sit unaided so to see him doing all these things is incredible. I think you take for granted all these little milestones but for Preston, itaposs a huge accomplishment. Heaposs amazed medical staff. He really is a Christmas miracle and he makes us proud every day. title: mum two 39 who complained
story: Mum of two, , who complained of back ache diagnosed with liver and spine cancerSarah Bennett, from Edgeley, Stockport, got her diagnosis just months after getting the all-clear for breast cancer. Now she is facing another tough battleSarah Bennett discovered she had liver and spine cancer just a few months after getting the all clear for breast cancer Image: MEN MEDIAByEthan DaviesLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Dec | commentsA mum of two was given a devastating double cancer diagnosis at the age of  after she complained of back ache.Sarah Bennett, from Edgeley, Stockport, has been diagnosed with liver and spine cancer just a few months after getting the all clear for breast cancer. She was first diagnosed with the disease in May  but got the all clear for it at the Christie Hospital  months later, reports the Manchester Evening News.Sadly, just a few months on from that moment, new scans found Sarah’s cancer had spread to her liver and spine, meaning she will have to undergo chemotherapy and radiotherapy simultaneously long-term. The secondary cancer was only found after she had a back ache — with nurses initially not worried about her pain. “I had a back ache and I rang my breast care nurse,” Sarah told the Manchester Evening News.  “She organised my scans to ease my mind. “She was not worried. “Then they found it in my liver and spine. It is really scary.” The latest cancer means doctors cannot give her a le expectancy for certain. “Realistically, I am not going to be here into old age,” Sarah added. “It has just been a bit of head f***.” “[Last year], I went into battle. You just get through treatment and carry on. After I finished, I struggled, because it’s almost like trauma. “Then I got the all-clear, but it did not stop there, as I had hormonal treatment so I was on medically-induced menopause. “Then, I got this diagnosis. “With the secondary one there’s no cure. They cannot give you a time scale, so you are living between scans.” To combat the latest cancers, Sarah has now started to have three weeks of chemotherapy every month to treat her liver, with radiotherapy for her back. The ‘anxiety’ of treatment, and uncertainty of not knowing how long she has left, is worsened by the fact that Sarah has a young family. The -year-old added: “If it was just me, I would crack on — but with the kids, they are too young to know what’s happening.” Along with Sarah is her fiance Ryan, and children Toby, age seven, and Maggie, who is two-years-old. Following the desperate news, friends of the family have rushed to Sarah’s aid.One friend who has stepped up is Jo Daly, who has set up anonline fundraiserto help the family pay the bills.Their financial concerns are heightened by the fact that both parents are self-employed, with Ryan a plasterer and Sarah a hairdresser, so when the pair cannot work, earnings take a hit. Jo told the Manchester Evening News: “They had two incomes and now they have half of one. “I would love to be able to write a cheque but we are not able to. Nobody is able to do it. “They just need to have that worry about paying the bills [removed]. “It is tragic that this is the situation and their biggest worry is money.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsBack painBreast cancerLe expectancyCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince charles accused staggering hypocrisy
story: Exclusive: Prince Charles accused of staggering hypocrisy as plane flies  miles to pick him upCritics say Prince Charles should have taken an electric vehicle to the Voyager aircraft’s usual home, RAF Brize Norton, in Oxfordshire rather than it being flown to SuffolkJust last month Prince Charles said we all had to reduce emissions urgently at COP Image: Getty ImagesByPatrick Hill:,  Dec | commentsPrince Charles has been accused of being full of hot air on climate change – after a plane flew  miles to pick him up. Critics say it undermines Charles’ Cop proclamation last month when he told the world: “We have to reduce emissions urgently. “We have to put ourselves on what might be called a war-like footing. We know what we must do.” The heir to the throne could have reduced his own impact on the planet by taking his electric vehicle to the Voyager aircraft’s usual home, RAF Brize Norton, in Oxfordshire. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Instead it was flown to RAF Mildenhall, Suffolk, nearer Sandringham, ahead of Charles’ trip for a ceremony removing the Queen as head of state. It saved him just two hours of driving time. Graham Smith of campaign group Republic accused Charles of “staggering hypocrisy” and called the flight a waste of taxpayers’ money and RAF resources. Matt Finch, of Transport  Environment, added: “For long distances we can’t avoid air travel, but for domestic travel, anyone should avoid flying and use other forms of transport.”  Charles, who has previously urged all of his staff to cycle to work, has championed the use of biofuels blended with normal aviation fuel as a transitional step towards creating carbon-free flight. The voyager, an Airbus A also used by senior Government ministers, is the first RAF plane to run on the “sustainable” option, but critics say it is still very harmful to the environment. Manufacturers claim it can cut a plane’s carbon emissions by up to  per cent, over its le cycle. But it is mixed with conventional jet fuel and scientists are unclear on how green it is. The prince is often driven to royal engagements in an all-electric Jaguar I-Pace SUV. And he also owns an Aston Martin DB, which he has said is powered by “surplus English white wine and whey from the cheese process”. Last month, Charles spoke of his passion for environmental issues during Cop in Glasgow and said world leaders need to do more than “just talk”, as he admitted he himself had been doing for the past  years. Today a Clarence House spokesman said: “The prince has campaigned for a sht towards sustainable aviation fuel as air travel is a crucial part of his work. “As a result, this autumn the RAF introduced for the first time sustainable fuel and deployed it for this trip. news uk-news prince-george-princess-charlotte-prince-"Royals release Christmas card photographsByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsMany families love nothing more than making Christmas the most magical time of year for children. And it seems Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louisaposs granny is no exception. Carole Middleton, mum of the Duchess of Cambridge, once revealed the very festive treat she gives her grandchildren at her house each year. In a previous interview, she told how she likes to spoil the little ones - by giving them their own Christmas tree in their bedrooms. She told theshe likes to have as many trees around the house as possible, including one in each of the grandchildrenaposs rooms so they can decorate it themselves.  The future kingaposs grandmother is said to have then taken a long pause, before admitting: That makes me sound as though I live in a mansion, doesnapost it  As well as daughter Kateaposs children, Carole is also a proud grandmother to her other daughter Pippaaposs children - Arthur and Grace - she shares with husband James Matthews. But despite getting their own trees at their grannyaposs house, one royal expert says Kate and her husband Prince William will be sure to try not to spoil George, Charlotte and Louis too much.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Royal expert Duncan Larcombe has said the couple will want their children to feel normal and won’t be lavishing them with expensive gts. Mr Larcombe told OK! that the family will be celebrating Christmas on their own, together with the more formal event at Sandringham with Williamaposs family and spending time with Kate’s family.  He said: I think we’re looking at three Christmases rolled into one for William and Kate and their children. “There will be Christmas on their own with their kids, the more formal celebrations at Sandringham with William’s family and then time with Kate’s family, the Middletons. But something we know for sure about William and Kate is that they want their children to feel normal and so they certainly won’t be lavishing them with expensive gts, that’s for certain. They won’t let them be spoiled.” William and Kate are likely to head to their beloved country home, Anmer Hall in Norfolk, on the Sandringham estate, as soon as they’re free of commitments in the run-up to the big day. They are then expected to join the Queen and other members of the Royal Family at Sandringham House on Christmas Day and attend the traditional church service. news uk-news shocking-moment-driver-reverses-down-"Car reverses down the hard shoulder to get out of traffic jam on the MByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsFootage shows the shocking moment a driver reverses down the motorway to get out of traffic.The M westbound saw bumper-to-bumper traffic this morning after a serious incident and drivers were stuck for several hours.One driver filmed the astonishing moment a car began to reverse down the hard shoulder in an attempt to get out of the traffic.The silver Toyota can be seen slowly reversing down the hard shoulder, alongside massive standstill queues, the Liverpool Echo reports.One driver was furious at the actions of one who was reserving during gridlock traffic.  David Carlyon, who filmed the incident, said: Some drivers make sick. Stuck in traffic on the M M slip road due to an accident and p***** wonapost wait and endanger other drivers by trying to get back on the M. Part of the motorway between junction  and  was shut from am as North West Motorway Police lead the response. Highways England tweeted: All traffic within the closure has now been released. The carriagway will remain closed for several hours for @NWmwaypolice investigation work. Please see enclosed link for ersion.The most recent update is that the M is still shut up between junction  and junction . It is estimated there is five miles of congestion and - minute delays on the approach. title: teenage coronation street fans day
story: Exclusive: Brave teen Corrie fans day of joy after being granted final wish to visit setDad Simon Cross recalled the touching visit to the Corrie set he made with his then -year-old daughter Hannah who had been diagnosed with cancerHannah Cross dream came true as she visited the set of Corrie Image: CollectByClaire OBoyleAssistant Features Editor Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsMarking his th birthday with a charity skye, Simon Cross felt on top of the world. He had raised £, for Make-A-Wish UK and liked their work so much he began volunteering for them.Four years later, the dad of two was on the set of Coronation Street with his young daughter Hannah as she was granted a wish by the charity after being diagnosed with cancer.“After seeing the whole process from the inside and helping families through the most heartbreaking moments of their lives, suddenly the roles were reversed,” says Simon. “I found myself on the other side, turning to Make-A-Wish for something that could bring comfort and joy to my own sick child.  “When we found out how ill Hannah was, our world fell apart.” He was an environmental health officer with the RAF in  when -year-old Hannah was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive soft tissue cancer. It was already stage four. Simon, , says: “By this point I’d volunteered with Make-A-Wish for three years and I’d always been in awe of how families I met dealt with what they were facing. I’d felt huge empathy for them, but I never pictured myself going through it.” Online: www.make-a-wish.org.uk mirror Text: To donate £ text the word LIGHT to . If you’d like to give £ but do not want marketing communications, text LIGHT NO to .You can text more than onceyou wish to donate more. Post: Please post cheques payable to MAKE-A-WISH UK to Freepost address below: Freepost Plus RUCS-LHTL-CJGU Make-A-Wish Mirror Appeal Make-A-Wish UK, Seventh Floor, Thames Tower, Station Road, Reading, Berkshire RG LX Hannah had a six-month course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Simon says: “She lost all her hair and parts of that time felt horric. “But Hannah was brilliant. However horrible it got, she kept on smiling. She was inspirational.” Afterwards, things seemed hopeful. She continued with maintenance chemo and, as her strength built up and her hair started to grow back, Simon and we Donna, , had more reason to be positive. They then decided to reach out to Make-A-Wish UK, this year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal charity. Simon, of Sleaford, Lincs, says: “I’d seen how having a wish granted could give families a real lt.” Hannah, then , asked the charity to arrange a Corrie visit for her and her family. Simon says the treat in November  was “wonderful”. He adds: “Make-A-Wish arranged a trip to Manchester over a couple of days. We were picked up in a limo from our hotel and taken to Granada Studios. By Jason Beattie For the majority of families this Christmas will be a joyous time of presents, food and fun. But for some children the festive season will be very dferent. Across the country there are more than , young people who are critically ill. Many will be spending what should be a special time of the year in hospital. Others will have to have treatment, scans or blood tests. With your help we can give them a Christmas that they will always remember. This year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal is raising funds for Make-A-Wish UK that helps seriously ill young people make their dreams come true.It could be they want to meet their hero or heroine or feed an animal at the zoo or travel to see Santa in Lapland. The money raised could help Joshua, six, who has severe epilepsy, achieve his wish of a bedroom makeover or Summer, also six, who has acute leukaemia and dreams of a bouncy castle. Each year Make-A-Wish helps hundreds of critically ill children achieve their letime’s ambition. But to make a wish come true takes an army of volunteers, supporters and donors. That’s why every penny you donate could make a dference. Granting a wish can transform a child’s le. It gives them something to look forward to. For others it provides a special memory which makes the treatment they need more bearable.It can also help their parents who, despite doing everything they can for their sick child, feel it is not enough. Jason Suckley, Make-A-Wish UK chief executive, said: “I met the family of a boy who was recovering from brain surgery. “His grandmother told me how dficult it had been for her to watch her daughter struggle with the challenges of her son’s condition.But while they were enjoying his wish together, her daughter turned to her and said, ‘There is still magic in this world isn’t there mum ’ . “That’s just one instance that illustrates how the power of a wish lies in sharing positive memories with loved ones. “Every donation from Mirror readers will help us create those memories – bringing joy to ill children and their families during the darkest of times.” “Hannah loved it. I remember we were greeted by Kate Ford, who plays Tracy Barlow, and she was lovely to us all. “Hannah loved walking around the set and seeing the cast. She got lots of autographs and loved meeting David Neilson, who plays Roy Cropper.” Hannah and her older brother Callum even had a stint as extras. Simon says: “She could feel normal for a day. She could forget about hospitals and scans and chemo and have a fun day with her family where none of that mattered.”  Then, just after Christmas in , Hannah noticed a lump in her neck and was taken back to hospital. It was on the day her appearance on Corrie was broadcast in January  that doctors gave the family the news that she had relapsed. “Still we hoped for a miracle,” says Simon, who will share her story at tonight’s Make-A-Wish Ball in London. She had more chemo but by September doctors said there was nothing more they could do. “We took her home from hospital and had her there for six days before we lost her on September , ,” Simon says. He adds his involvement with the charity gave him – as well as his we and son Callum, now  – a reason to stay positive.  Simon says: “Everyone is dferent in how they grieve, but for me carrying on with Make-A-Wish helped.” The year after Hannah’s death, Simon set about an amazing challenge in her honour. “She was  when we lost her,” he says. “So I decided to do  half marathons. I raised money for a number of charities, including Make-A-Wish. “I had a sign with me with a picture of Hannah. Every time I was struggling I remembered all she had been through and it helped me keep going.” He still volunteers with the charity and says of the granted wish: “We’ll never forget the joy it brought her.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON David NeilsonKate FordCoronation StreetHospitalsSoap operasCancerMirror Christmas appealXmas Appeal " data-immediate"data-immediate"Dont miss out on the biggest soaps gossip! news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-five-days-"UK weather: Outbreaks of rain and strong gales expectedByIsobel FrodshamMillie Cooke:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAnother blast of snow is set to blanket parts of Britain as thousands of people face a second weekend without power a week after deadly Storm Arwen.The latest weather maps suggest Britain is in for at least five consecutive days of snow from Saturday, with much of it falling over higher ground in the north of the country.The overnight windchill could be -C over the coming days, according to one forecast, and strong winds are likely on Tuesday and Wednesday.The Met Office said the weather is predicted to be cold, windy and showery with some hilly areas experiencing snow on Saturday. Snow is also expected to fall in parts of eastern England, the North Yorkshire Moors and parts of Lincolnshire while strong winds and widespread rain are also predicted for the North West. The forecaster said Scotland will be cloudy in the morning with outbreaks of rain and hill snow on Saturday, but drier and brighter by the afternoon with a few showers in the west. Northern parts of the UK will see highs of Cwhile the south will see highs of C . Sunday will continue to be cold with some hill snow and showers in the east of England while the west is predicted to have dry weather and some sunshine. Frost is expected in colder parts of the UK, including central and western Scotland where temperatures may drop to -Cand -C .  A band of rain on Monday will be preceded by snow that could be widespread in Scotland, northern England and the Midlands, and North Wales, a map from Wxcharts suggests. Maps also suggest further snowfall in the same areas on Tuesday into the early hours of Wednesday morning. Tuesday will become increasingly windy. Overnight windchills could be -C in parts of Scotland, including the Cairngorms, according to snow-forecast. Steve Keats, meteorologist at the Met Office, said: “In some ways, we’re expecting fairly typical early December weather this weekend and nothing too disruptive as expected. “But a couple of points to watch for will be winds, which under normal circumstances wouldn’t be an issue butyou’re trying to repair downed power lines it’s more sensitive. “Saturday is expected to be cold. There will be quite a mild windshield coming down from the northwest, so it’s going to feel not much above freezing for quite a lot of places. “Soyou’re out and about doing the Christmas shopping, put on some extra layers.” Meanwhile, thousands of Brits are facing a second weekend without power. Homes across parts of Scotland and the North East and North West of England are still off supply a week after Storm Arwen hit on November . As of early Friday evening, just over , homes were without power, according to industry body the Energy Networks Association. Regulator Ofgem announced on Friday it had launched an “urgent” review into the response of energy network companies to the storm.Met Office five-day forecastSaturday Rain clearing eastwards, then most parts seeing a mixture of sunny spells and blustery showers. The showers heaviest and most frequent in the north and west, whilst more persistent rain and hill snow affects northern parts. Cold and windy. Saturday night Clear spells and showers, these mostly in areas exposed to the northwest. More persistent rain and hill snow affecting some eastern parts. Remaining windy, but frosty in sheltered spots.SundayFurther showery rain across some eastern areas, perhaps edging into central parts but dying out. Sunniest across western parts as showers die out. Winds easing but staying cold.Monday to WednesdayBand of rain moving east Monday, preceded by snow, mainly on hills. Wet and increasingly windy Tuesday, with coastal gales in the west. Staying windy with blustery showers on Wednesday. title: brit couple tried save baby
story: Brit couple tried to save baby first as all three died on remote hiking trailJonathan Gerrish, , who was originally from Lancashire, we Ellen Chung, , their one-year-old daughter Muji and the familys dog, Oski, were all found dead in the Sierra National ForestJonathan Gerrish, his partner Ellen Chung and their one-year-old daughter Image: Rossana HeaslettByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Dec | comments A British couple who hyperthermia and dehydration on a remote hiking trail in Calornia likely tried to save their baby first, reports say.Jonathan Gerrish, , who was originally from Lancashire, we Ellen Chung, , their one-year-old daughter Muji and the familyaposs dog, Oski, were all found dead in the Sierra National Forest on August . A survival trainer involved with the case told detectives in an email that it was likely the couple died while attempting to save their infant daughter.Sadly, I believe they were caught off guard, and once they realised their situation, they died trying to save their child and each other,apos the unidentied trainer said, according to the Daily Mail.  It is likely the child began to succumb first, which hurried the parentsapos efforts up the hill. When one could no longer continue, they stayed behind to care for the child and pet, while the other tried to forge on and get help for their loved ones. It is a tragedy of the highest order. Detectives had a number of theories behind their deaths, which included suicide, being poisoned by toxic material, in the water, or a freak lightening strike.  But police have since confirmed the group died from hyperthermia and dehydration. Their eight-year-old dog Oski also suffered a heat-related death, police said. Jonathan, Ellen and Muji were found . miles from their vehicle in temperatures which could have soared above F , Mariposa County Sherf Jeremy Briese said.  They were found with one empty water bottle and a bottle of formula between them, which indicated the heat and lack of sustenance likely contributed to their death. For Mariposa County, this is rare, Sherf Briese told reporters at a conference. This is the first hyperthermia cause of death that Iaposve witnessed here in  years. title: employee gobsmacked after being asked
story: Employee gobsmacked after being asked to pay £ towards CEOs Christmas presentAn unimpressed employee took to Reddit to complain after their HR department at work sent them an email requesting that they send over their £ present contribution for their boss presentsHe couldnt believe it Image: Getty Images PhotoAltoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Dec | commentsFor many employees, a Christmas party or a bonus goes a long way after a year of hard work. But one unhappy employee was furious after they were asked to put towards their bossapos Christmas presents.The anonymous person shared a screenshot of an email from their HR department reminding them about their contribution to Reddit, where they said: That money is going to my kids, not to the fat cats at the top who make at least x what I make on any given month.Buy your own damn presents. Responding to criticism they were receiving about supposedly making a big fuss over nothing, they wrote: At first I felt bad that I wasn’t contributing, but the more I think about it, the more pissed off I get that they’d even ask us to pitch in like that. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. There’s nothing anyone can buy those people that they can’t already go out and buy on a regular, everyday trip to Walmart. I don’t hate working here, but I do hate this kind of attitude toward employees, with families, at Christmas time. A final edit read: Iaposve already told anyone with any relevance to the situation that I wonapost be pitching in. I havenapost gotten any flack, most of them understand where Iaposm coming from. Since being posted, just a few days ago at the time of writing, it has been upvoted more than , times and has received , comments, the majority of which are from users who agree that the poster should refuse to contribute. One person suggested: Put  monopoly money in an envelope. Another wrote: I hate this. Yes, let me spend my hard-earned money on someone that takes expensive vacations every month. A third commented: Only time Iaposve actually participated in those was the time I actually had a wonderful boss. But she was like my actual director who I saw and worked with and talked to every single day. Not the CEO of an entire company who you probably donapost see too much of or even know personally. In reply, the poster explained: Itaposs a small company so we all see each other on a daily basis and Iaposve had many one-on-one interactions with said CEO. Not a bad person, from what I can tell. Just a f***ed up ask of her employees. Granted, itaposs probably the HR lady thataposs orchestrating all of this, but it would be nice to see CEO say aposNah. Yaposall keep your money, and hereaposs a little extra.apos Others shared bad experiences of their own, with one person revealing: Back when I worked for a big restaurant chain, HR took  dollars from everyone’s salary to give the CEO an expensive painting for his th birthday. The guy is a multimillionaire... While another user commented: They used to do this at my last job. Passed around a birthday card and collected money to buy the boss a new BBQ. The same boss that owned  houses and an airplane.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman finds unlikely romance after
story: Woman finds unlikely romance after her date arrives with four of his matesTikTok influencer Paige Bryan has revealed how she ended up meeting a man after her original date turned up to their first date with four of his friendsPaige couldnt believe it when five men showed up at her date Image: Tiktok paigebryanofficialByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Dec | comments Weaposve all had our fair share of dating horrors, although there are few of us who can say weaposve ever had a date bring four of friends along for the ride. Youaposre probably thinking, apossurely no one would do that,apos but thataposs exactly what happened to one TikTok influencer, but the disaster had an unlikely ending. TikToker Paige Bryan, who posts from the handle @paigebryanofficial, addressed her followers by telling them: Welcome to this episode of dating sucks, and I hate it here.In the clip, Paige revealed she was  and just re-entering the world of dating when she went on a night out with her girls, where she met someone who she had an instant connection with. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. We didnapost have to say a word, we just mystically started floating through the crowd into each otheraposs arms. The song ends, I put in my number. We donapost need words because we have passion, she explained. We end up making plans to go to dinner. The following weekend, Paige arrived at the restaurant where she and her date had planned to meet. She gave the hostess her dateaposs reservation name and she started walking to their table, where the TikToker realised there was six seats and place settings at the table. He arrives about  minutes later and I notice he walks in the restaurant at the exact same time as another group of beautul male specimens. I wave him down and I notice they all, yes all, start walking towards me, she added. They all start to pull out a chair and take a seat, while he hugs me and tells me I look great. But Iaposm thinking so weaposre not gonna address the fact that you brought Jim, James, Paul, and Tyrone to our date. Paige continued: So then I end up asking, aposto what do I order the discomfort of ALL your company,apos to which he responds, aposOh, you donapost mind do you apos Yes. Yes I do mind, and heaposs like, aposmy bad, I should have asked first.apos Anyway, SHOCKER, he ended up being a horrible date. I mean we are talking zero personality, like in the negative of personalities. But, despite the night being a complete and utter disaster between Paige and her date, it did take an unlikely turn when she ended up getting to know his friend. So needless to say I never saw him again but did I  percent start dating his friend who was a million times more interesting than him  she added. Yes, yes I did. We do love a happy ending.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-relentlessly-bullied-nose-birthmark-"TikToker is proud of her birthmark despite being mocked for itByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Dec | commentsA woman who has a birthmark on her nose has hit back at haters who make fun of her. Raven, a -year-old from New York, has a birthmark on the tip of her nose that she says people on the internet often mock her for. As a child, she was offered surgery to remove the birthmark, but instead of undergoing the procedure, Raven has chosen to love and embrace her birthmark, believing it makes her unique.Raven uploaded a video showing off the birthmark on her TikTok @babyravey, with the caption: Be you, do you, there is so much more to people than what meets the eye. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. In the clip, she addressed hate from trolls, writing: When someone makes fun of my birthmark on the internet but I f**cking love it and embrace being unique every day of my existence. Since being posted, the video has racked up almost one million views, , likes and hundreds of comments from people who said how cool they think the birthmark is. One person said: I was teased relentlessly for mine as a child, Iaposd laugh in anyoneaposs facethey tried making fun of me for it now. Itaposs YOU. Beauty transcends. Another wrote: Honestly, thataposs pretty cool. A third commented: This is so cute, you look like a teddy bear. Someone  put: Growing up I thought I was the only one in the world with one, made me feel so insecure. Got it removed. I wish I had your confidence as a kid. One TikTok user commented on Raven’s video suggesting that she would remove it in a heartbeatshe could, to which Raven replied, saying: I have had bodily autonomy as long as I can remember and my parents doctor always gave me the option but I just love myself instead. Options when I was young were limited and would have resulted in scarring or just a lighter birthmark. I’m good on that.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news your-local-fish-chip-shop-"History of fish and chipsByCourtney PochinSenior Audience WriterNisha Mal:,  Sep Updated:,  Dec | commentsSometimes thereaposs nothing better than finishing work on a Friday night and swinging by your local fish and chip shop on the way home to treat yourself to an easy dinner - be it a piece of plaice, cod, a pie or a battered sausage.The same goes for grabbing a portion of chips to enjoy during a day spent lazing around by the seaside.But when staff in the chippie hand over your order, do you instantly smother your food in salt and vinegar  If the answer is yes, weaposre about to tell you something that might shock you.It turns out the aposvinegarapos served in your local fish and chip shop probably isnapost real vinegar, as was first reported by WalesOnline.  This startling piece of information comes courtesy of YouTuberTom Scott, who revealed in a recent video that many chippies instead use something known as a non-brewed condiment in place of vinegar. Youaposve probably never been able to tell the dference between the two, as it looks very similar to the real thing and only tastes slightly dferent. A non-brewed condiment is a malt vinegar substitute made from water, acetic acid and ious flavourings - yummy! It takes less time to make than actual vinegar and can be purchased in concentrated form.  It also possesses several other benefits that the real stuff doesnapost have. For example, it doesnapost contain any alcohol, making it halal and a great choice for teetotal customers. Some batches of the condiment are also gluten-free, meaning businesses can cater to a wider range of people with it. But the real question is, will discovering this industry apossecretapos put you off using the aposvinegarapos in fish and chip shops in the future  Let us know in the comments below. Do you have a food secret to share  We want to hear all about it.
