title: covid vaccine in scotland track the rollout progress with these charts
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: what is canoe polo
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowNo matter how frustrating the Covid clerical fiasco has been, there is no excuse for taking it out on vaccination staff at clinics.They have worked beyond the call of duty during the pandemic and continue to be there to help us.Questions, however, must be asked over the management of the Covid booster programme.Senior NHS Highland and HSCP managers must bear responsibility for the needless mistakes, many of which a little local knowledge could have quickly rectied.We detected, in the response to our enquiries, a note of irritation at NHS staff time taken up addressing media questions as the confusion unfolded.The situation is entirely of NHS senior management#s making, and the media has every right to ask questions of a publicly-funded service on behalf of the people of Argyll and Bute.We hope and trust, however, that the admin problems have now been resolved.That aside, thank you to all the NHS staff helping each of us by delivering vital Covid booster jabs # it is genuinely appreciated while the virus remains a threat.And this Sunday at am, let#s think about others who made unimaginable sacrices on our behalf.Lest we forget.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 19 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: co op defends argyll and bute pricing policy
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt is central to many rural communities, but the Co-op has faced recent criticism of its pricing and stocking policy in Argyll.What the Co-op does have in its favour is excellent local staff in these stores, but the cost and iety of goods has been questioned # something beyond the control of store staff.Peter Bates, deputy convenor of Tarbert and Skipness Community Council, has taken up the cause after noticing substantial dferences in the price among a iety of goods between Oban supermarkets and the Tarbert Co-op branch.On November  he wrote on the #All Things Tarbert# Facebook page: #The Co-op board and executive really need to have a hard think about their pricing policy, stocking policy and supply issues.#The price dferences between shops in Oban and the Co-op was made startlingly aware to me on our last shopping trip:#Honeydew melon # Oban £., Tarbert £.#Tarbert Co-op has destocked several items over the past year, but they are readily available on the Lochgilphead Co-op shelves. It is not #green# to have to do a -mile car journey for essentials.#The Co-op also seems to be replacing many branded items with their own products which are nowhere near as good.#He believes this policy is #pricing out rural living#, and continued: #It is particularly hard-hitting for those less mobile, non-car owners and the elderly.#Come on Co-op, a change needs to happen.#His post attracted a big response # with people in other parts of Argyll and Bute supporting his views.Mr Bates has since written directly to the Co-op, but emphasised: #The excellent hard-working management and staff at the Co-op in Tarbert are a big part of our community and are very helpful and kind. They have no control over pricing and stocking policy, which is decided by the board.#Stressing that the supermarket operates a UK pricing policy, a Co-op spokesperson said: #Co-op is committed to serving and supporting its rural communities, conveniently, including areas where other retailers often do not trade due to the increased operational costs.#Like all retailers, Co-op has experienced some patchy disruption to the availability of some products, and it is working with suppliers to re-stock as quickly as possible.#Alongside well-known brands, Co-op#s award-winning own-brand products provide shoppers with choice # delivering quality and value, while also enabling customers and community causes to unlock additional value and benefits through its membership programme.#Mr Bates added: #The Co-op bosses in Manchester need to realise that the Tarbert Co-op and others in rural locations are not convenience stores. These are often the only store for miles and are therefore leline stores.#If they do not understand this, then they do not understand the communities they are serving.#Speaking on Wednesday this week, Mr Bates said he had received no reply from Co-op management.He said ##apart from an automated receipt reply, I have heard nothing further. I intend to send the e-mails again.#PIC:Co-op acknowledged #patchy disruption to the availability of some products# but said Argyll store pricing policy is the same as across the UK. _acoopemptyshelvest-co-op-logo-no

title: mccallum-hoping-world-title-eliminator-vegas
story: Galashiels boxer John McCallumrsquos IBF Intercontinental Cruiserweight title fight against Kazakhstan fighter Issa Akberbayev at York Hall was postponed at the last minute.The fight had been scheduled for Friday  November but Akberbayev withdrew citing illness two days before.A previous fight between the pair was called off by Akberbayev due to Covid.A frantic search to find another opponent for the McCallum failed and he is now in talks about a world title eliminator in Las Vegas next month.A disappointed McCallum told the Border : ldquoThat fight was for meant to be for my dad Steven Robinson who is seriously ill with cancer in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital and that has been taken away.ldquoI had a massive support and many of them were spending the weekend in London.ldquoIrsquom really annoyed and it has even made me think of chucking it. The whole thing has been a massive disappointment. It wasnrsquot about belts or money it was for my dad and as soon as I found out I drove to Edinburgh to be with him.ldquoI donrsquot think Irsquoll be fighting Akberbayev again after the two call offs. This was an oral virus which meant he was unable to fly.ldquoIrsquove been asked to fight Andrew Tabiti who is in the Mayweather camp for a world title eliminator which would take place in Las Vegas on -December at the Mandalay Bay and Irsquom up for that. The Intercontinental belt is still vacant butthis comes off Irsquoll bypass that.ldquoI peaked for the Akberbayev so Irsquoll have a few days rest then get back in training at my local gym before heading to Vegas about five days before the fight. Irsquom in good shape so that should be OK.

title: date-announced-next-years-maroond-gala-festival
story: BUILDING on its success in , the Maroonrsquod@Gala sports and music festival willto Netherdale next year.The event will take place at the home of Gala Rugby, on Saturday, August , .Praised for its innovation and inclusivity, the inaugural edition of Maroonrsquod@Gala provided competition opportunities for primary school age rugby players under s under s under s senior and ladies sections and players with physical and learning disabilities.It also played host to football and running events.In addition to the showpiece sporting event ndash which culminated with the final of the famous Gala Sevens - there were live bands, street food, themed drinks areas and fun zones.Despite challenging weather conditions and the requirement to work in accordance with government coronavirus guidance, the free  event was attended by around ,-, people.It received positive feedback with participants, vendors and spectators stating their intention tofor future editions.Ian Dalgleish, the president of Gala RFC, said: ldquoThe Maroonrsquod@Gala concept has been very well received and the success of our inaugural event this summer, coupled with positive feedback and the continued support of our partners, has given us confidence to bring it back in .ldquoTogether, wersquore committed to creating a community event that local people want to be part of and to celebrate the proud sporting history of Gala Rugby, as well as to inspire our future stars."We also want to build on what we achieved this year and to extend the feel-good factor beyond the Netherdale site, maximising the positive economic impact in Galashiels town centre.Maroonrsquod@Gala was initially scheduled to take place in April  but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Further details will be announced in due course.

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: bench-memory-selkirk-singer-unveiled-home-town
story: DOZENS of people turned out to the unveiling of a commemorative bench in memory ofFrightened Rabbit frontman, Scott Hutchison in the grounds of Haining House on Saturday, November .The former stately home which was given over to the public to be used as an arts centre was chosen as the perfect location for the beautully crafted oak bench which has the words ldquoWhile Im alive, Irsquoll make tiny changes to the earth emblazoned across the front.These words were taken from the lyrics of Scotts song lsquoHead Rolls OffrsquoScott took his own le in May  after suffering from depression and a charity in his name was launched to raise awareness about children and young peoplersquos mental health issues.The bench was made by three trainee female carpenters, and was crowdfunded by fans with money left over from another bench that was situated in Kelvingrove Park in .Ade Cartwright, the organizer of the bench fundraiser, said in a statement: ldquoThis bench is for all those out there who have been touched by Scottrsquos lyrics and music, his humour and humanity. Itrsquos a place to put the headphones on and listen to his music and take a deep breath of fresh air, a place to sit down and have a good catch-up with friends, a place to celebrate Scottrsquos le and what he means to all of us. Also to just rest your weary legs, itrsquos a fair trek!To donate to the charity, visit https:tinychanges

title: langlee-coronavirus-pcr-test-site-depriving-residents
story: THE Bordersrsquo site for PCR coronavirus tests is lsquodeprivingrsquo residents of a vital community hub, a meeting has heard.The walk-through test site at Langlee Community Centre is operated by the UK Governmentrsquos Department of Health and Social Care.During a full council meeting last week, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked the council whether it would find a dferent site for the testing station after receiving concerns from a community group.Mr Scott said that the continued use of the centre by the NHS is ldquodenying the use of the large hall and cafeacute to the groups who normally use those facilities.:Peebles woman was found with large quantity of cocaine worth more than pound,Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar ndash the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport ndash said that the site has ldquohigh usage.ldquoThe UK Government has asked that the PCR test sites remain operational until March , he said. ldquoThe current lease expires in January .ldquoThe Langlee site is the only PCR site in the Borders. It has a high usage which is anticipated to increase over the winter period.ldquoIt is in a relatively central location within the most populated Borders locality. Five groups were displaced from Langlee, all five groups were offered alternative provision.Responding, Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoI appreciate the need to support the NHS in the early stages of this horrible pandemic but things have moved on now.ldquoThe other side of the coin is this centre in Langlee is in the middle of one of the areas that houses some of the poorest and socially deprived iniduals in the Borders.ldquoThis centre is vital in the maintenance of their mental health and wellbeing.:Man stole money from Borders busker after throwing bottle at wall, say policeldquoI donrsquot think itrsquos acceptable that this Langlee community is deprived of this centre for any longer than is necessary..removeAccording to Mr Scott, he has received correspondence from NHS Scotland stating that the ldquorequired facilities for a testing station are not overly prescriptive.Mr Edgar said that Scottish Borders Council officers are ldquoactively engaged in finding alternative sites.However, the independent councillor said that the requirements of any potential new site ndash including the need for safe queuing, separate entry and exit routes and sufficient toilet facilities ndash is making this dficult.He said that the old school buildings at council headquarters had been looked at but were discounted due to space and accessibility issues.Mr Edgar added that empty retail units in Galashiels had also been considered.PCR tests can also be accessed through mobile testing units and home test kits, according to NHS Borders.

title: galashiels-former-borders-college-campus-plans-revealed
story: PLANS for the former Borders College campus in Galashiels have been revealed.Eildon Housing has acquired the ldquokey site as part of plans to provide ldquomuch-needed high quality affordable rented homes.Nile Istephan, CEO of Eildon Housing, says the housing association is working closely with the council to produce a ldquodetailed proposal for the site.:Man stole money from Borders busker after throwing bottle at wall, say policeldquoWe have acquired the site of the former Borders College, on Melrose Road, Galashiels which has been lying vacant for many years now, he said. ldquoThis site offers a great opportunity for Eildon to provide much needed affordable homes to rent in a popular, central area of the town.Mr Istephan added: ldquoThis is a signicant regeneration site, and we will be able to provide a range of housing options to meet known local needs, as well helping the Borders meet sustainability and climate change targets. Our investment also generates high quality local training and employment opportunities.The former campus plans form a part of Eildonrsquos ldquorecord-breaking expansion of housing and care services in the Borders.Building work may not start until the summer of , according to the housing association.

title: peebles-charity-launches-text-campaign-childrens-clothes
story: A BORDERS charity has launched a fundraising text appeal to help it provide local youngsters with essential clothing.Peebles-based Tweed Togs has been operating since  to make high-quality, pre-loved clothing available for children aged  and under.And now the charity is running a lsquoWinter Wunder Wearrsquo campaign to raise money to buy essential garments ndash such as underwear and pyjamas ndash for youngsters across the Borders.Details of items needed are regularly posted on the charityrsquos Facebook page.Susan Walker, Tweed Togsrsquo chair, said: ldquoUsing our Facebook page to request specic donations of clothing is working really well.ldquoOur most urgent need is funding for underwear and pyjamas.ldquoEvery referral is provided with a set of new pants, socks and vests and as more and more requests have been made, Tweed Togs need to quickly replenish these stocks.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the charityrsquos ability to fundraise has been reduced.However, it received a grant from SPIFOX ndash an organisation which raises money for childrenrsquos causes in Scotland ndash but this money is due to run out.The charity says that since August demand for its services has ldquoincreased rapidly week on week as it has received referrals from more than  dferent agencies across the Borders.To date, it has provided clothing to more than  children around the region.Tweed Togsrsquo services are free and totally anonymous and recipients of the clothes receive their packages within  days of receipt of the referral.Referrals to Tweed Togs can be made by healthcare professionals, schools, charities, the Citizens Advice Bureau, churches and support groups.It offers seasonally appropriate clothing, as well as underwear, which is then packaged into gt bags for the youngsters.Due to limited storage space at its base in Peebles Business and Art Hub, Tweed Togs ensures any excess clothing donations avoid landfill and are reused or recycled..removeMs Walker said: ldquoThe generosity of local people and businesses is absolutely astounding.ldquoWe are hugely grateful to our volunteers and followers who give of their time and services freely and to those who take time to donate beautul pre loved clothes.To donate to the Winter Wunder Wear campaign, text PANTS to  to donate pound, or to donate pound text PJS to .For more information, including details of requested items, visit Tweed Togs Facebookpage.

title: work-start-soon-gala-fairydean-rovers-stand
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers hope to reopen their iconic Netherdale Stand for the start of next season.The Peter Womersley designed building has been closed since winter  due to public health and safety concerns associated with spalling concrete.A structural assessment was initially conducted in  highlighting the required repairs needed to the stand.Concrete Repairs Limitedhas been appointed to carry out a range of improvements to the category A listed building. The work includes concrete repairs to the stand and turnstiles, drainage improvements and aesthetic enhancements around the stand to restore some of its original features.The work will be funded by Scottish Borders Council within this yearrsquos capital budget along with a contribution from the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Community Trust.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoAnyone who is familiar with the town of Galashiels will recognise the iconic architecture of the Netherdale Stand and its importance to the town.ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to see work on repairing the building to its former glory progress with the appointment of an experienced contractor.ldquoEnsuring its long-term future by carrying out these necessary refurbishments will allow future generations to benefit from it andthe stand to its former glory.Murray Souter, regional director for Scotland at Concrete Repairs Limited, said: ldquoConcrete Repairs Limited are delighted to be entrusted with the refurbishment of this iconic structure and our team are looking forward to spending the spring and summer months of  in Galashiels working.ldquoTogether with Scottish Borders Council and their design team, we willthe stand to its original glory, looking great, structurally sound, and ready to cope with a full complement of excited Gala Fairydean Rovers fans.The news was also welcomed by Ross Buchan, chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Community Trust..removeHe said: ldquoThe stand repair project has been a long journey which began for us in October . The stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoWe have now reached a signicant stage on this journey, where, Scottish Borders Council have appointed of the principal contractor to carry out the works. We welcome Concrete Repairs Limitedonto the project and look forward to working in cooperation and partnership with them also.ldquoIt will be a day to celebrate when the stand is opened to the public, club and community where we can once again make full use of this very important facility.ldquoThe project has benefitted from working in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

story: Parent Power for the Sunday TimesSchools Guidehas named its top Scottish schools for .There are dferent lists for state and private schools, with institutions in ious areas making the cut.These schools are ranked by their pre-pandemic exam results in  and .Bishopbriggs Academy has beennamed Scottish Secondary School of the Decade, having risen through the ranks.The school only broke the top  in , and this year has been named number  on the state school list.Hereare the Sunday Times best Scottish schools for ...The top  state secondary schools in Scotland. title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. There are currently over  across Scotland and the network continues to grow.Officers also say that taking part in the lsquoYour Police Surveyrsquo is one way for people to express their views and needs.Responses to Your Police Survey helps officers identy and eliminate obstacles and barriers for anyone who needs them and they would encourage everyone to take part to influence policing in their area.Your Police Survey is available in easy read and British Sign Language formats.Take part here http:ow.ly BXwHPh

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-ticket-sale-figures-really-good
story: FIGURES around the number of tickets sold for the Great Tapestry centre have been described as ldquoreally good.The visitor attraction, which opened in Galashiels in August, was discussed at a full council meeting on Thursday, November .During the open questions section of the virtual gathering, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked how many paying customers have visited and how much revenue had been made.Responding, fellow Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that , tickets have been bought, with pound, generated since its opening to the public.According to Mr Jardine, those numbers are ldquoin line with the revised business case projections made in February which included coronavirus implications on visitor numbers.Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoThatrsquos quite gratying. In these dficult times those figures are very good.ldquoI look forward to the facility enjoying better times ahead.Ahead of the centre opening, the council said it would ldquoattract over , visitors to Galashiels each year ndash creating  jobs and almost pound, of extra spending per annum.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-report-recommend-fee
story: OWNERS of electric vehicles in the Borders could soon have to pay to charge their vehicle, it has been revealed.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told a meeting last week that an upcoming report will recommend the local authority charges for the service.The plans could be put to elected officials as early as January, according to Mr Edgar.Responding to an open question from Hawick representative Davie Paterson on the issue, the independent councillor said: ldquoA condition of earlier Transport Scotland grant funding for electric vehicle charging points was that they were free at the point to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.ldquoThis condition has now been removed and Scottish Borders Council, like other local authorities, should be considering introducing a charging regime.He added: ldquoA report on the issue is currently being prepared and will recommend that the council introduces a charging regime going forward.Mr Edgar told the meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was pound,.Meanwhile, Borders MP John Lamont says that an out of order charging point at Tweedbank Railway Station is ldquonot helping people in the Borders use electric vehicles.Figures from the Department for Transport show that there are a total of  electric vehicle charging devices available for public use in the region.But Mr Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, says the station charger has been out of action for two months.ldquoI am keen to see electric vehicle use become more practical for people in the Scottish Borders, he said. ldquoHowever, cases like the broken charging point at Tweedbank Station are not helping.ldquoWe need to make sure we have a fully-ing electric vehicle charging network. That is why I have written to Scottish Borders Council to try and get the charging point fixed as quickly as possible..removeldquoAs we continue to increase the number of EV charging points here in the Borders, we must ensure that they are well maintained.The Borders is set to benefit from pound, of UK Government funding to support the development of electric vehicle charging points, according to Mr Lamont.On the funding, he said: ldquoI am very pleased that almost pound, of funding will go towards the expansion of our EV charging point network as part of the UKrsquos community renewal fund.ldquoI also appreciate that Scottish Borders Council will be taking on the responsibility of looking after them.

title: west-linton-host-first-live-coffee-concert
story: A BORDERS village is set to host its first live coffee concert.During the coronavirus pandemic the West Linton Village Centre hosted a number of virtual music events, however, the centre will now welcome a live audience for Twogether Duo.Twogether Duo, formed of Alena Bulatetskaya from Russia on classical accordion and Huixin Hu from China on violin, will perform a range of numbers, including classical pieces, folk songs, and Christmas favourites.And in the interval guests can enjoy a cup of coffee or tea with a choice of home-baked treats for free.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe Coffee Concerts series have been made possible courtesy of a grant awarded to the VC from the CAF Tourle Foundation and with the assistance of Live Music Now Scotland.Spaces for the Coffee Concert are limited, and tickets can be booked by emailing westlintonvillagecentre@gmail or by calling texting  . For those who are unable to attend in person, the performance will be streamed via Zoom. To register, click here.Twogether Duo will perform at West Linton Village Centre on Saturday, December  from -.pm.

title: winning-return-peebles-burgh-silver-band
story: PEEBLES Burgh Silver Band recently won the th Section of the Borders Entertainment Contest.On November  at The Buccleuch Centre in Langholm, Peebles Burgh Silver Ban joined a number of other Borders bands following the contestrsquos postponement last year due to the coronavirus pandemic.The bandrsquos musical director Peter Holmes prepared the programme which featured Philip Harperrsquos arrangement of Fat Bottom Girlsby Queen, The Road and the Miles to Dundeearranged by Alan Fernie, and I Will Follow Youfrom Sister Act.The band retained the trophy they won at the  competition.At the weekend the band performed at the annual Christmas lights switch-on in Peebles High Street.Peebles Burgh Silver Band now plans to perform on the High Street each Saturday morning throughout December from .am ndash weather permitting ndash and will host a Christmas Concert on Friday, December  in the Burgh Hall.Speaking about these upcoming events, a band spokesperson said: ldquoAll of these are much needed fundraising events for the Band following  months or so of no fundraising.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to sponsors and donors most recently The Provincial Grand Lodge of The Scottish Borders who provided a grant towards Youth Band tuition.ldquoWithout actions like this we would be unable to offer the free tuition and instruments to all.ldquoPBSB will be delighted to see you over the festive period and greatly appreciate all the local support it receives.Members of the Peebles Burgh Youth Band will also perform at the concert. Tickets for the concert can be purchased from band members or on the night.

title: travellers-england-face-pre-departure-tests-nigeria-added-red-list
story: All travellers arriving in England will be required to take a Covid- pre-departure test ndash while Nigeria is being added to the Governmentrsquos travel red list, Health Secretary Sajid Javid has said.Mr Javid said the Government had decided to move after receiving new data about the spread of the Omicron iant, which emerged in southern Africa.ldquoSince we have learned of this new iant our strategy has been to buy time. We have always said we will act swtly should new data require it, he told broadcasters.ldquoOver recent days we have learned of a signicant number of growing cases linked to travel with Nigeria.ldquoThere are  cases already in England and thatrsquos growing. Nigeria now is second only to South Africa in terms of linked cases to Omicron.The Department of Health and Social Carelater said the correct figure was .The Scottish and Welsh governments said they were both adopting similar controls.Under the new rules, from am on Monday only British and Irish nationals travelling from Nigeria will be allowed into the country and must isolate in a government-managed quarantine hotel.And from am on Tuesday, anyone travelling to the UK from countries not on the red list will be required to take a pre-departure test a maximum of  hours before leaving, regardless of their vaccination.And ndash from am Tuesday, anyone travelling to the UK from countries not on the Red List will be required to take a pre-departure test, regardless of their vaccination status.  mdash Sajid JavidDecember , The announcement will be seen as evidence of the mounting concern within Whitehall of the threat posed by the Omicron iant.However, the requirement for pre-departure tests was greeted with anger and dismay across the travel sector ndash just as bookings were picking up with the approach of the Christmas break.Tim Alderslade, chief executive of the industry body Airlines UK, said the rapidly changing measures meant planning for travel was becoming impossible..removeldquoIt is premature to hit millions of passengers and industry before we see the full data. We donrsquot have the clinical evidence, he said.Vaccines remain our first line of defence ndash the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones. Please get vaccinated or #GetBoostedas soon as you can.  mdash Sajid JavidDecember , ldquoTheyrsquove now changed their travel advice twice within a week and itrsquos just impossible for anyone to plan. These measures must be removed as quickly as possible in line with the speed of the booster programme.The Airport Operators Association chief executive Karen Dee said it was aldquodevastating blow for aviation and tourism, and said the Government should step in to support the industry.vw,vw,px, px"ldquoPre-departure tests acts as a major deterrent to travel and most of the limited remaining demand following the reintroduction of self-isolation will now fall away, just as airports were hoping for a small uplt over the Christmas holiday, she said.ldquoThe UK and devolved governments should have done the right thing and, alongside the restrictions, announced support for our businesses and our staff to get through another period of shutdown.The DHSC said new analysis by the UK Health and Security Agencysuggested the window between infection and infectiousness may be shorter for the Omicron iant, increasing the efficacy of pre-departure testing as it is more likely to identy positive cases before travel.For Labour, which has been calling for the re-introduction of pre-departure tests since the iant was identied, shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper welcomed the move but said ministers should have moved sooner.ldquoWe badly need them to learn the lessons on the importance of acting quickly on Covid border measures rather than each time having to be put under huge pressure to finally act.Nigeria joins  other African nations ndash Angola, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe ndash on the red list.vw,vw,px, px"Mr Javid however stressed the Government was still looking to the expanded vaccination programme as its main weapon in the fight against the spread of the disease.ldquoIt is important to remember while we are introducing these new border measures today vaccinations are our first line of defence The expansion of the booster programme is hugely important, he said.The HSA said that as of Saturday a further  cases of the Omicron iant have been reported across the UK ndash  of them in England.It takes the total number of confirmed cases of the iant in the UK to .On Friday the HSA said that in England Omicron cases have now been identied in East Midlands, East of England, London, North East, North West, South East, South West and West Midlands.Iniduals who have tested positive for the iant and their contacts are being asked to self-isolate while the HSA said it was carrying out targeted testing at locations where the positive cases were thought likely to be infectious.The figures came as a risk assessment by the HSA rated the Omicron iant as ldquored for severity of infection and ldquoamber for transmissibility between humans.It said the iant was likely to reduce the protection from both naturally or vaccine-acquired immunity.However it acknowledged there was so far ldquoinsufficient data to reach firm conclusions and the assessment was presented with ldquolow confidence.HSA chief executive Dr Jenny Harries said: ldquoWe are working as fast as possible to gather more evidence about any impact the new iant may have on severity of disease or vaccine effectiveness.ldquoUntil we have this evidence, we must exercise the highest level of caution in drawing conclusions about any signicant risks to peoplersquos health..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Travellers to England face pre-departure tests as Nigeria added to red list

title: sir-lewis-hamilton-nothing-grenfell-deal
story: Sir Lewis Hamilton has said he had ldquonothing to do with Mercedesrsquo F teamrsquos partnership deal with Kingspan ndash an insulation firm linked to Grenfell Tower.Sir Lewis is competing with the team at the Saudi Arabian Grand Prix this weekend.Kingspanrsquos logo appeared on Sir Lewisrsquo car for the first time on Saturday.Speaking at a press conference after the qualying session, Sir Lewis said the decision had ldquonothing to do with him.vw,vw,px, px"Kingspanrsquos K insulation was one of the products installed on Grenfell Tower during its refurbishment ldquoIt is not something that I feel I have to speak about publicly, he said.ldquoI had nothing to do with the team signing any of the sponsors. Tommywas the only one I probably brought to the team.ldquoIt was news to me when I heard the things that have happened this week and I was very aware and watching closely all the families affected by what happened there.ldquoWe know there has been a huge outcry and an amazing amount of support by people in the community around there.ldquoIt is really nothing to do with me and I know Totois sorting it.ldquoUnfortunately my name is associated with it because it has been on my car but whether that remains the same, we will see.Sir Lewis has previously written about the Grenfell Tower fire on his Instagram account.vw,vw,px, px"Mercedes boss Toto Wolff apologised to Grenfell survivors and bereaved relatives over the deal In , he posted a picture with a caption that said: ldquoToday marks three years since the horric Grenfell Tower fire in London.ldquoRemembering the  souls we lost and their loved ones, and everyone affected by this tragedy.On Friday, Mercedes-AMG Petronas F team principal Toto Wolff apologised to Grenfell survivors and bereaved relatives, and thanked campaign group Grenfell United for an offer to meet following its condemnation of the deal with Kingspan..removeThe group had written to Mr Wolff urging him to end the deal.Responding to them in a letter, Mr Wolff wrote: ldquoThe tragedy of the Grenfell Tower fire was beyond imaginable to me, and it should never have happened.ldquoOn behalf of our team, I would sincerely like to apologise to you for the additional hurt that this announcement has caused.ldquoIt was never our intention to do so.ldquoThe work of the public inquiry to establish the full causes of the tragedy is crucially important.Mr Wolff said that before concluding the partnership, his team ldquoengaged with Kingspan in depth to understand what role their products played in what happened at Grenfell.He said: ldquoKingspan have stated that they played no role in the design or construction of the cladding system on Grenfell Tower, and that a small percentage of their product was used as a substitute without their knowledge in part of the system which was not compliant with building regulations and was unsafe.vw,vw,px, px"Grenfell survivors have asked Mercedes to end its sponsorship deal with Kingspan Meanwhile, Communities Secretary Michael Gove said the Government could amend advertising rules on racing carsMercedes does not pull the partnership with Kingspan.An inquiry is examining how Grenfell Tower came to be coated in flammable materials which contributed to the spread of flames, which shot up the tower in June , killing  people.Kingspanrsquos K insulation was one of the products installed on Grenfell Tower during its refurbishment, although the majority of the insulation used on the west London tower block was made by another company.In a statement released on Friday, Kingspan said it played no role in the design of Grenfell Towerrsquos cladding system.ldquoThe Grenfell Tower fire was a tragedy that should never have happened, and Kingspan supports the vitally important work of the inquiry to determine what went wrong and why, the company said.ldquoKingspan played no role in the design of the cladding system on Grenfell Tower, where its K product constituted approximately % of the insulation and was used as a substitute product without Kingspanrsquos knowledge in a system that was not compliant with the buildingrsquos regulations.ldquoThe new partnership with the Mercedes-AMG Petronas Formula One team reflects the ambitious sustainability targets of both title: sunday-times-schools-guide-2022---see-top-schools-scotland
story: Parent Power for the Sunday TimesSchools Guidehas named its top Scottish schools for .There are dferent lists for state and private schools, with institutions in ious areas making the cut.These schools are ranked by their pre-pandemic exam results in  and .Bishopbriggs Academy has beennamed Scottish Secondary School of the Decade, having risen through the ranks.The school only broke the top  in , and this year has been named number  on the state school list.Hereare the Sunday Times best Scottish schools for ...The top  state secondary schools in Scotland.
